jUnit relies on a certain amount of implicit meta-data.  This is via
the naming of methods.  Making that meta-data explicit frees one from
having to name tests in a certain way.  

Also, through annotations, one can test for exceptions without
try/catch/etc simply by declaring which exception(s) a test should return.

But the real reason is de-coupling.  With annotations you don't need
to inherit from a framework (jUnit) class.  You simply annotate the
class and it becomes a TestCase.  This means you don't need to break
out your tests into separate classes (though one is still free to do
so).  To switch contexts entirely, its one of the reasons I like
Hibernate over Cayenne.  Both great, but Hibernate (unlike Cayenne and
most others) makes no requirements on the POJOs being persisted. 
Thanks to annotations, nUnit has the same claim: any method in any
class can participate in unit testing.  This flexibility can lead to a
 more natural development style and more freedom for the developer.
